newsitem.title: UK: LME copper breaches support, nickel, tin slide.
newsitem.headline: LME copper breaches support, nickel, tin slide.

text.p: LME copper prices crumbled below $2,100 support on Monday afternoon as spreads eased and ahead of inventory data expected to show more metal in exchange warehouses.
Many of the other metals joined the slide with tin hitting fresh 19-month lows and nickel touching a new 26-month nadir.
Three months copper ended the afternoon kerb at $2,081 per tonne, down $51 from Friday and only $1 off the low for the day.
"I think we're going to see softer prices now that the tight December dates are mostly out of the way," said one senior floor trader.
The premium of cash over three months metal eased again after third Wednesday pricing went smoothly in the morning, disappointing some who had expected some volatility.
It was last indicated at a $55 backwardation compared to a $100 backwardation on Friday.
Floor traders said they expected LME inventories to rise again on Tuesday after a build of 7,225 tonnes on Friday.
Several traders said they expected stocks to rise by 8,000-10,000 tonnes, although one trader thought they could increase as much as 12,000 tonnes.
Nickel dropped to its weakest since October 1994, as three months metal ended the kerb at its day's low of $6,510, a loss of $125.
Technical analysts said the confirmed breach of $6,600 support, where it bottomed out on November 18, weakened the chart picture and made further falls to $6,400 likely.
Tin slipped to a low of $5,680, the lowest since May 12, 1995, but it edged up slightly by the end of the day to $5,685, a loss of $90.
The market had been hit by fund liquidation recently and soft technicals, traders said.
Aluminium, however, ignored the weakness in the others and managed to gain $6 to $1,516 after exploring a low of $1,507.
Zinc eased $8 to $1,045 and trade was light in lead, which finished indicated at $689/90, down slightly from $695 on Friday.
